elements.text: Show the Alphabet Cards for letters
Say the letter aloud and have children repeat.
makes the /i/ sound you hear in the word
makes the /i/ sound you hear in
Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters
Say the letter aloud and have children repeat.
makes the /j/ sound you hear in the word
makes the /j/ sound you hear in
Today we will read about the letter
. Then we will read a book about the letter
Tap your shoulders when you hear a word that begins with the /i/ sound.
Snap your fingers when you hear a word that begins with the /j/ sound.
Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters
Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.
top at each word that begins with the letter
Have children say /i/ and the word that begins with
Some children will benefit from tracing letters in trays of salt or sand.
For a challenge, after reading each story, ask children try to recall all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Also, for the letter
encourage children to name words with
is pronounced like the English letter
. Help children who are familiar with that letter and that sound make the transition to saying the /j/ sound when they see the letter

Children who struggle to maintain attention may need a reminder about the sound they are listening for. Before reading each page in the alphabet books, remind children of what sound they should be listening for.

. We saw how the animals used their imaginations and used persistence in order to build the playground in just one week. They worked really hard!
Now its our turn to work really hard. Lets use our imaginations to make a really fun playground.
Were going to use play clay to make our playground.
Each of you can make one thing for the playground!
Then well put all the things together for our own special playground.
Allow time for children to work on their creations. As children work, circulate and ask questions. Compliment the children on their the way they are persisting.
Can you describe what you are making? How will someone use it at the playground?
Make sure to compliment initiative when you hear a child volunteering an idea.
Invite children to help you put together the playground. Then have them share their ideas about the different objectshow they were made and how they can be used.
Did you enjoy using your imagination?
If you had more time, what would you add to the playground?
Some children may have difficulty using the play clay and getting it into the shape they want. Offer help with any part that is causing frustration.
Some children may enjoy the challenge of first drawing their plans before creating them. Provide paper for anyone who wants to plan their project.

As children work with the different colors of play clay, take this opportunity to talk to them about the objects they made. Use color words and compliments, such as I like that green circle you added to your playground object. Can you name the thing you are making?
Some children may lose interest and say they are finished very quickly. To keep them busy, ask them to make some extra balls of play clay that you can later use to add to the playground.
. TM  &  Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Today we read a story called
about a team of builders who use trucks and big machines to make a playground. We read about lots of things that go in
Now lets talk about more things that go.
Today lets find other words that are things that go. I will show you some wonderful pictures of things that go. Then we will talk about them.
Show each Activity Card one at a time and ask children to identify the object they see.
After each card, ask children to tell you what other vehicle this one reminds them of. Then chant together, Lets take a ride. Lets go, go, go!
Continue the activity with the rest of the cards.
Guide children to tell about all the vehicles they remember reading about this week. Then distribute drawing paper and ask them to draw one vehicle they like. Help them label their drawings.

Help children remember the vehicles that they read prior to this lesson by displaying the Big Chart. Name the vehicles together. When children are asked to name another vehicle that the one shown reminds them of, guide them focus on one detail, such as wheels.
To challenge children, give them three-page blank booklets. Invite them to draw three different vehicles. Help them label the vehicles. Add their books to the class library.
English learners may not be familiar with some of the vehicle names in this activity.
To help to make them feel comfortable, before starting show them the photos and name the vehicle. This way they will be better able to participate in the group activity.
Children who have visual difficulties may need to hold the cards themselves so that they can better see the images. Note any visual problems that are new.
. TM  &  Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Today we looked at some words that rhyme. We found rhymes for words in
Today we are going to play a listening game.
I am going to say two words.
If the words rhyme, youre going to jump up and down until I say, Freeze.
If the words dont rhyme, youre going to sit down.
Then I will say two more words.
. Do the words rhyme? Yes, they do. Now jump up and down until I say, Freeze.
Use the following word pairs to continue the game.
smash; crash 	splash; flash	slide; ride
race; chase	go; stay		run; sit
car; star		fly; sky		treasure; measure
If time permits, say one of the words and ask a child to say a word that rhymes.
Talk about how much fun it is to listen for rhymes. Then ask children if they can think of word that rhymes with a word you say.
Can you name a word that rhymes with
Can you name a word that rhymes with
Before beginning the activity, use some simple rhymes to establish whether or not the children understand the meaning of rhyme and can identify simple rhymes.
Children may enjoy the challenge of coming up with a third word for each of the rhyming sets. You also might want to encourage them to make up some silly nonsense rhymes that will make them giggle.

As children work, carefully monitor any difficulties they have. Rather than changing this activity, use it to consider why children may struggle. Assist them to relieve frustration, but take mental notes about children who may be experiencing particular difficulties.
If you have children in your class for whom jumping up and down is difficult, modify the activity so the responses children should make accommodate the abilities of all.
